titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York Records
1785-2014
MS 2997
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Luis Rodriguez

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-01-30T15:11-0500

did.unittitle: Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York Records
did.abstract: The collection contains records (1785-2014) of the Saint Andrew’s Society of the State of New York, a Scottish-American charitable and social organization. The records document the organization’s administrative history, membership, charitable efforts, and cultural events. All material is restricted for 50 years from its creation.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Saint Andrew’s Society of the State of New York was founded in 1756 to provide charitable relief and promote social ties within the growing Scottish-American community. It followed the founding of Saint Andrew’s Societies in Charleston (1729), Philadelphia (1747), and Savannah (1750), as well as the Scots Society of New-York (1744-1753). In 1775, meetings were suspended due to the Revolutionary War. At that time the Society’s membership included both British officers and American revolutionaries. Three members—Philip Lawrence, Lewis Morris, and John Witherspoon—were signers of the Declaration of Independence. In 1784 the Society reorganized and resumed its original mission. There are few records from this early period, however, because in 1835, most documents, including the original constitution signed by the founding members, were lost in a fire.

The Society’s membership was initially open only to Scottish men and their sons and grandsons. In 1897, membership was opened to men of any Scottish lineal descent. The membership of the society involved many political, commercial, and cultural leaders. During the Civil War, a number of members served in the 79th New York Volunteer Infantry, nicknamed the Highland Guard. Other prominent members include: Philip Livingston, William Livingston, Robert R. Livingston, Alexander Hamilton, John Loudon McAdam, Washington Irving, Andrew Carnegie, James Gordon Bennett, Alexander Graham Bell, John Lindsay, and Thomas J. Watson Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Saint Andrew’s Society of the State of New York Records document several significant aspects of Scottish and American history in New York. As a social club that attracted prominent individuals to its leadership and events, and as an aid organization that served Scots in need, the Society produced records that reflect the lives of a wide variety of people within the New York area’s Scottish community.
The records contain many types of material, including minutes, financial ledgers, committee records, and ephemera.
The collection is arranged in the following six series:
Series I: Administrative Records
Series II: Charitable Records
Series III: Membership Records
Series IV: Event Records
Series V: The Pibroch
Series VI: Miscellaneous Historical Material
A more detailed description of the contents of each series is included in the container list.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
acqinfo.p: Gift of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York, 2015

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: This collection is owned by the New-York Historical Society. The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers. Portions of the collection that have been microfilmed will be brought to the researcher in that format and can be made available by Interlibrary loan. Researchers on site may print out unlimited copies from microfilm reader-printer machines at per-exposure rates. See guidelines in Reading Room for details. Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.) Items that include presidential signatures will be presented to researchers in duplicate form.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as The Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York Records, MS 2997, The New-York Historical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials Note
relatedmaterial.p: The Printed Collections of the New-York Historical Society hold a collection of material related to Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York under the call number F128 HS2725 .S14.
There is also a small amount of oversize archival material, separate from this collection, at the New-York Historical Society labeled: Y-Saint Andrew's Society.

controlaccess.subject: Charities -- New York (State) -- New York
Clubs -- New York (State) -- New York
New York (State) -- Social life and customs
controlaccess.title: Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York
Scottish Americans--New York (State)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to the operations and management of the Society as a whole. It is arranged into subseries that detail the organization's institutional structure, which includes an early treasurer's book, minutes, reports, printed histories, committee records, and office files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The treasurer's book is a manuscript general ledger documenting the society's income and expenses from 1785 to 1860. Treasurer's records for the period after 1860 exist within the subseries Minutes and Annual Reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Minutes (1835 - 1989) provide an account of the Society’s activities and include information related to charitable giving, membership, constitutional changes, and other facets of the organization’s operation. Bound minutes are in some cases supplemented, or in later years, replaced by foldered material that includes correspondence, agendas, copies of reports, and the minutes themselves.

General Meeting minutes (1835- 1990) record the larger meetings called by the President to elect officers, receive annual reports, form committees, and otherwise express the intentions of the Society as a whole. These include Annual, Semi-Annual, Preparatory, and various Special Meetings. Bound minutes exist from 1835 to 1960. Foldered material runs from 1950 to 1990.

Minutes of the Board of Managers (1884 - 1989) record monthly meetings that address changes in membership, review monthly financial and charity reports, and attend to other business as needed. Bound volumes cover the period from 1884 to 1966. Foldered material exists from 1953 to 1989.

Some of what is contained in General Meeting minutes in relation to reports and officers can also be found in the subseries Annual Reports. Likewise, information related to the membership of individuals in the Society can also be found in the series Membership.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: General Meeting minutes are arranged first, followed by Board of Managers' Meeting minutes. Each set of minutes is ordered chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Annual reports published by the Saint Andrew’s Society of the State of New York contain summaries of activity which may include: lists of officers and committees; financial statements; reports from Secretaries, Almoners, various committees, and other officers; lists of active members; “in memoriam” notices; and the organization’s constitution.
Annual reports from the years 1873 to 1976 are bound in hardcover volumes. Duplicate paperback volumes are housed separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Brief printed notices contain lists of officers, reports of the Secretary, meeting schedules, statements regarding dues, and other announcements. They are arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Lists of officers and reports of the Secretary
Lists of officers and reports of the Secretary

Directories and schedules for Board of Managers

Directories and schedules for Board of Managers
Directories and schedules for Board of Managers
Subseries I.5: Constitution, Rules, and History

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Society periodically produced publications, in addition to the annual reports, that compiled various types of organizational information. These items include governing rules and narrative histories that describe the leadership and activities of the organization over time. They are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Governance Committee Records primarily document the process of selecting members to lead and administer the work of the organization. The Nominating Committee selected officers, chaplains, physicians, and members of the Banquet Committee. The Standing Committee appointed a Finance Committee and attended to other executive business. The subseries contains correspondence, meeting minutes, lists of candidates, and related material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Nominating Committee records are arranged first, followed by the records of the Standing Committee. Each set is ordered chronologically.

did.unittitle: Subseries I.7: General Files of the Recording Secretary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: General files held by the Recording Secretary document the routine administrative affairs of the Society. Correspondence frequently involves presidents and other officers in the organization. Material is arranged chronologically.

did.unittitle: Questionnaire on War Affairs: Members Serving
Questionnaire on War Affairs: Members' Sons
General File re: Saint Andrew's Day, the admission of women as members
Honorary Member Certificates, Ian W. McDonald
General Correspondence and Greetings, Robert Coe
"The Pride of the Clyde Celebrations" promotional material
Cypress Hills Cemetery correspondence with photocopies of material ca. 1920 - 1950

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Charitable records document the Society's mission to provide aid to individuals of Scottish descent. Responsibility for the dispersal of aid originally fell to the Board of Managers, until 1841, when the Society hired an Almoner to investigate cases and provide aid. In addition to the primary fund, special funds were also established for specific charitable purposes, which can be seen in the President's Fund and Scholarship Fund subseries.

did.unittitle: Subseries II.1: Manager's and Almoner's Record Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains ledger volumes that detail individual requests for aid and corresponding disbursements made by the Society. The volumes are in chronological order.

did.unittitle: Account of Burials and Record of Hospital Cases

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The reports contain monthly summaries of individual cases overseen by the Almoner. The files are ordered chronologically
See also the reports contained in the published Annual Reports in Series I.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains files kept by the Almoner related to individual applicants and recipients of aid. Material includes correspondence, applications, and related documentation. The files are arranged alphabetically according the the applicant's name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The President’s Fund was established in 1944 in response to the effects of World War II in Scotland. Separate from the Permanent Fund, which could only be spent in New York, it allowed the Society to supply aid to Scottish charities at the discretion of the President. Records in this subseries consist chiefly of correspondence related to individual donors and recipient organizations. There are also administrative reports on the status of the fund.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Scholarship Fund (1955 – 1992) was established as part of the Society’s Bicentennial celebrations. For the majority of its history, it provided financial aid to Scottish students wishing to study in American universities and vice versa.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Material in this subseries was filed in two categories prior to processing. The first was a general file containing administrative correspondence, fundraising material, program information, and other records. The second contained correspondence and records related to the individual scholarship recipients. This arrangement is preserved under the headings “Committee records”, which is arranged first, and “Student files”, which follows. There is, however, some overlap between the two categories. Each set is ordered chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Membership records contain information about the individuals who have belonged to the Saint Andrew’s Society of the State of New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The series consists of the following subseries: Registers, Member Applications, "Archived" Member Files spanning the period from the 1850s to the 2000s, and "Unarchived" Member Files, spanning the period from the 1850s to the 1980s. The archived and unarchived member files reflect the arrangement of the material at the time of accession. Archived files are foldered, and unarchived files are housed in original envelopes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Bound volumes are arranged first, followed by foldered material. Within the bound volumes, manuscript material is first, followed by typescripts, and then printed matter. Apart from those considerations, items are ordered chronologically according to their date of creation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The subseries contains historical lists of members compiled mostly during the early 20th century.

did.unittitle: Typescript roll of members from 1756 to 1910
Roster of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York with Biographical . Part I...1756 - 1783
Biographical register of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York, Vol. 1 1756 - 1806
Register of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York. Third Series, 1857 - 1906
Biographical register of Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York. Vol. 2, 1807 - 1856
Membership lists copied from early documents, 1770 - 1820

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Member applications contain information about individuals wishing to join the Society. Volumes are arranged chronologically. Within the volumes, however, the applications are organized alphabetically by name. See also the subseries Member Files, which contains unbound applications.

did.unittitle: Proposals for Membership. Duplicate Missing Records of members on the roll 1846 - 1908

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Member Files contain application materials and correspondence related to an individual’s involvement in the Society. All refer to inactive members. "Archived" Member Files reflect the filing system from about the 1990s to the time of accession. They therefore include the files of members active in the 1990s and 2000s. Additionally, many earlier member files, primarily although not exclusively those with last names beginning with 'A' through 'C', had been interfiled into this subseries. See also the following subseries Unarchived Member Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Member Files contain application materials and correspondence related to an individual’s involvement in the Society. All refer to inactive members. “Unarchived” Member Files reflect the filing system from about the 1850s to the 1980s, and the files remain housed in their original envelopes. See also previous subseries Archived Member Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Records of events held by the Society contain ephemera and transcripts from Anniversary Banquets, memos and correspondence involved in the planning of various events, and photographs of the events themselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains ephemera and transcriptions of the proceedings at the Society's Anniversary Banquets. Included are menus, programs that detail guests and seating arrangements, and in some cases, the text of speeches given on the occasion. Bound volumes are arranged first, followed by foldered material. Duplicate items are housed separately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains records produced by the committees responsible for organizing events held by the Society. The primary events concerned are the Anniversary Banquets, Golf Tournaments, and Tartan Balls. Material is arranged chronologially.

did.unittitle: The Black Watch, Scottish Games, and Gathering of the Clans
Spring Dinner Dance and Tartan Ball
Duplicate Tartan Ball and Anniversary Banquet committee records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains photographs documenting the social and cultural events held by the society. The majority are focused on Anniversary Banquets and gatherings related to Tartan Week.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The photographs are arranged in rough chronological order. Loose photographs and photograph albums are housed together.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The Pibroch was the newsletter published by the Saint Andrew's Society of the State of New York from 1944 to 1994. It featured reviews of meetings, member news, reports from officers, pieces of cultural and historical interest, and information related to social events.

The series is divided into two subseries. The first subseries consists of the published issues of the Pibroch. The second subseries, publication records, contains files held by the editor of the Pibroch. The Recording Secretary was typically responsible for editing the newsletter, and the files include mockups, page proofs, clippings, copyright forms, and correspondence. Material is arranged chronologically within each subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous Historical Material contains items of historical value informally collected by the Society. While direct historical documentation such as constitutions or printed histories is contained primarily in the Administrative Records series, this series gathers material such as clippings, reproductions, photographs, and printed matter that complements material found elsewhere in the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Material from Saint Andrew's Societies based in other locations contexualizes the work of the Saint Andrew's Society in New York. Items are arranged chonologically.

did.unittitle: Photocopy of "Rules and Orders agreed upon by the Scots Society in New-York"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Reproductions, scrapbooks, clippings, and ephemera span nearly the full history of the institution.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook compiled by George Austin Morrison Jr.
Ephemera related to Saint Andrew's Society and its members

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes signed menu, certificate, booklet from Central Park monument restoration, and other material.

did.unittitle: Booklets and souveniers not related to Saint Andrew's Society
Printed matter related to Scottish subjects
Scrapbook of material related to victims of September 11 attack

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous photographs include portraits, meeting photographs, and images of places and occasions related to the activities of the Society.
